description: Diabetes is a long-term chronic disease and a lifestyle-related illness. When insulin production is insufficient or the body's cells have reduced insulin sensitivity, it leads to abnormal metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins, causing elevated or unstable blood glucose levels.
symptoms: Polyphagia: Feeling hungry despite eating a lot
Weight loss: Losing weight despite increased food intake
Tingling or numbness in the feet
Female-specific symptoms: recurrent yeast infections, polycystic ovary syndrome, etc.
Other symptoms: acanthosis nigricans, scalloped tongue, facial pigmentation
diagnosis: Random blood glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL with related symptoms
Fasting blood glucose after 8 hours ≥ 126 mg/dL
Oral glucose tolerance test (75g): blood glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL at 2 hours
Gestational diabetes diagnosis: fasting ≥ 92, 1 hour ≥ 180, 2 hours ≥ 153 mg/dL

general: Control weight, quit smoking and limit alcohol, manage stress, get regular check-ups, ensure sufficient sleep, and care for your feet
diet: Maintain a balanced diet including grains, vegetables, fruits, beans, fish, eggs, meat, dairy, and fats
Reduce intake of refined sugars, high-fat foods, and sugary drinks
Use low-oil and low-salt cooking methods such as steaming, boiling, and stewing
Eat at regular times and control carbohydrate portions
exercise: Engage in at least 150 minutes of aerobic exercise weekly, such as brisk walking, swimming, or cycling
Do resistance training to build muscle mass
monitoring: Regularly check blood sugar, blood pressure, and blood lipids
Drink more water to support bodily functions and blood sugar stability
lifestyle: Maintain a healthy weight and avoid obesity
Keep feet clean and dry, and avoid injuries

risk_factors: BMI ≥ 24 or waist circumference ≥ 90 cm for men / ≥ 80 cm for women
Metabolic syndrome or polycystic ovary syndrome
Impaired glucose tolerance or elevated fasting glucose (100–125 mg/dL)
High blood pressure or being treated for it
HDL cholesterol < 35 mg/dL or triglycerides ≥ 250 mg/dL
History of giving birth to a baby weighing over 4 kg or having gestational diabetes
Use of medications like steroids, diuretics, or contraceptives
complications: Infections (e.g., tuberculosis, liver abscess, skin infections)
domestic: The prevalence of diabetes in Taiwan among those aged 18 and over is about 11.1%
Prevalence among those aged 20 and over is 12.8%
Over 90% of cases are type 2 diabetes, with a trend toward younger onset
The prevalence among men is slightly higher than among women
1 in 4 adults is in the prediabetic stage, and 90% are unaware of it
Among men over 65, the prevalence can reach 28.5%
The prevalence of diabetes in Taiwan is higher than the global average
ethnic: Black, Latino, Native American, Asian American, and Pacific Islander populations are at higher risk of type 2 diabetes
Type 1 diabetes has higher genetic susceptibility among Whites and is more common in colder regions
Type 2 diabetes is influenced by both genetics and lifestyle, with prevalence varying across ethnic groups
Lifestyle, environment, and socioeconomic status affect diabetes risk
Genetic variations and their links to diabetes are key research focuses
Different ethnicities may require different screening standards
